title: Partisan Pressures Weigh Heavily as Senate Looks for Coronavirus Relief Deal
sub_head: Nearly all senators belong to the party that won their state’s presidential contest in November
body:
The 50-50 Senate that is trying to find agreement on a coronavirus relief bill isn’t just evenly split. It is also operating under partisan pressures that, by one measure, are greater than ever.
Some 94 senators belong to the party that won their state’s presidential contest in November—a record-high level of party allegiance for at least 54 years, an analysis of data gathered by the Pew Research Center shows. That leaves a record-low six senators as political mismatches with their home state’s presidential choice: Three Democratic senators represent states that backed former President Donald Trump, and three Republicans come from states that President Biden won.
Just two weeks since Mr. Biden took office, it remains unclear how the dynamics of the divided Senate will affect his legislative agenda, which includes a proposed $1.9 trillion coronavirus relief plan.
With more voters siding with a single party, current and former senators say, it may mean many lawmakers have less flexibility to work with the opposing party to strike deals—a necessity in a chamber where 60 votes are needed to pass most legislation.
That presents a potential challenge for Mr. Biden, who has made calls for national unity a central theme of his presidency and has said he wants bipartisan support for his coronavirus response proposal and some other priorities.
